class goo.goo.Force(force_name, cell_name, strength, falloff_power, collection_name, type)[source]

Bases: object

Creates Force (Python) objects.

The class instantiates Force objects that represent adhesion forces between cells in Blender.

Parameters

  • force_name (str) – The name of the force.

  • cell_name (str) – The name of the cell.

  • strength (float) – The strength of the force.

  • falloff_power (float) – The power of the falloff of the force.

Returns

None

Note

falloff_power is a positive (float). By default, the type of the falloff is set to SPHERE and its shape is set to SURFACE.

force_list = []

Returns

The Blender force obj.

Return type

float

Returns

The strength of a Blender force.

goo.goo.add_boundaries(loc, size, shape='BOX', type='REFLECTIVE', name='box')[source]

Adds reflective boundaries to the scene.

The boundaries can be of the shape of sphere or boxes.

Parameters

  • loc (tuple) – A tuple containing X, Y, and Z coordinates of the center of the boundary.

  • size (tuple) – A tuple containing dimensions in X, Y, and Z for the boundary.

  • shape (str) – The shape of the boundary. Supported values are ‘BOX’ and ‘SPHERE’.

  • type (str) – The type of boundary. (Unused parameter in the provided code)

  • name (str) – The name to be assigned to the boundary object.

Returns

None

goo.goo.add_hetero_adhesion(cell_name, other_type_name, strength)[source]

Adds heterotypic adhesion force between a cell and cells of another type.

This function creates a heterotypic adhesion force between a cell and cells of another specified type. The adhesion force is applied to the cell based on the specified strength.

Parameters

  • cell_name (str) – The name of the cell to which the heterotypic adhesion force will be applied.

  • other_type_name (str) – The name of the other cell type to which the adhesion force will be applied.

  • strength (float) – The strength of the heterotypic adhesion force.

Returns: None

goo.goo.add_homo_adhesion(cell_name, strength)[source]

Adds homotypic adhesion force within a cell type.

This function creates a homotypic adhesion force within a cell type. The adhesion force is applied to the specified cell based on the specified strength, and it affects other cells of the same type.

Parameters

  • cell_name (str) – The name of the cell to which the homotypic adhesion force will be applied.

  • strength (float) – The strength of the homotypic adhesion force.

Returns

None

goo.goo.add_material(mat_name, r, g, b)[source]

Creates a soap bubble-like Blender material for use in rendering cells.

The material has a name that allows it to be shared across multiple cells.

Parameters

  • mat_name (str) – The name of the material.

  • r (float) – The value of the red in RGB [0 to 1].

  • g (float) – The value of the green value in RGB [0 to 1].

  • b (float) – The value of the blue value in RGB [0 to 1].

Returns

None

goo.goo.add_motion(effector_name, strength, persistence=0, randomness=1, distribution='uniform', size=0.5)[source]

Adds motion force to a cell.

This function creates a motion force effector based on the specified parameters and links it to the corresponding cell.

Parameters

  • effector_name (str) – The name of the cell object to which the motion force will be applied.

  • strength (float) – The strength of the motion force.

  • persistence (float) – The persistence of the motion force (default is 0).

  • randomness (float) – The randomness of the motion force.

  • distribution (str) – The distribution type of the motion force (default is ‘uniform’).

  • size (float) – The size of the distribution for the motion force.

Returns

None

goo.goo.add_world_HDRI()[source]

Sets up Blender World properties for use in rendering.

It adds an HDRI image for illumination.

Returns

None

goo.goo.apply_modifiers(obj, which='all')[source]

Apply modifiers to a Blender object.

This function applies modifiers to a Blender object, either all modifiers or a specific one, based on the ‘which’ parameter.

Parameters

  • obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object to which modifiers should be applied.

  • which (str) – Specifies which modifier(s) to apply. Default is ‘all’. If ‘all’, all modifiers are applied; otherwise, specify the name of the specific modifier to apply.

goo.goo.apply_physics(obj, stiffness)[source]

Apply cloth physics and related modifiers to a Blender cell object.

This function sets up cloth physics and associated modifiers for the provided Blender object. It includes Subdivision Surface (Subsurf), Cloth, Collision, and Remesh modifiers.

Parameters

  • obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object to apply physics to.

  • stiffness (float) – Stiffness value for Cloth modifier.

Returns

None

goo.goo.calculate_com(cell)[source]

Calculates the center of mass of a Blender cell object.

Parameters

cell (bpy.data.objects[cell.name]) – cell

Returns

The coordinate of the center of mass of the cell.

Return type

tuple(x,y,z)

goo.goo.calculate_volume(obj)[source]

Calculates the volume of the Blender mesh.

In order to retrieve the mesh as it is currrently evaluated - including the effect of all modifiers - in the simulation, its corresponding evaluated ID is obtained from the dependency graph for the current context.

See also

[Blender API Documentation > evaluated_get(depsgraph)] (https://docs.blender.org/api/current/bpy.types.ID.html?highlight=evaluated_get#bpy.types.ID.evaluated_get)

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender mesh.

Returns

The volume of the mesh.

Return type

float

Note

The function may return a negative volume. See calc_volume(signed=True).

goo.goo.cast_to_sphere(obj, factor=0.5)[source]

Apply a Cast modifier to round up a cell object.

This function applies a Cast modifier to the provided Blender cell object, creating a rounded shape.

Parameters

  • obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object to be rounded.

  • factor (float) – The factor to adjust the level of rounding. Default is 0.5.

Returns

None

goo.goo.constrict(obj, indices)[source]

Constricts selected vertices along a line defined by the center of mass and the long axis of the object.

This function constrains the selected vertices of the given object along a line defined by the center of mass (COM) and the long axis of the object. The selected vertices are resized to create a constriction effect.

Parameters

  • obj (bpy.types.Object) – The Blender cell object to constrict.

  • indices (list[int]) – A list of vertex indices to be constricted.

Returns

None

Parameters

  • cloth_settings (dict) – A dictionary storing Cloth modifier settings for each modifier.

goo.goo.disable_internal_springs(objects)[source]

Disable internal springs for Cloth modifiers in a list of Blender cell objects.

This function iterates through the provided list of Blender objects and, for each daughter cell object, checks if a Cloth modifier exists and disables internal springs.

Parameters

objects (list) – A list of Blender cell objects.

Returns

None

goo.goo.divide_boolean(obj)[source]

Divide a cell object along its division plane using boolean operations.

This function performs boolean division on a Blender cell object, creating two daughter cells. It also handles the declaration of daughter forces, inheritance of properties, and separation of the mesh.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object to be divided.

Returns

  • bpy.data.objects[‘name’]: First daughter cell.

  • bpy.data.objects[‘name’]: Second daughter cell.

  • float: Adhesion strength.

  • float: Motion strength.

  • float: Falloff.

  • bool: Flag indicating if there was a mother adhesion force.

  • bool: Flag indicating if there was a mother motion force.

  • list: List of dictionaries containing values of the modifiers applied to the original object before division.

goo.goo.get_cells_same_type(obj)[source]

Get cells of the same type.

This function retrieves cells of the same type as the provided Blender object, and looks across different collections. Checks the type custom properties of a Blender object.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object representing a cell.

Returns

A list of cell Blender object of the same type.

Return type

list

goo.goo.get_centerofmass(obj)[source]

Calculates the center of mass of a mesh.

This function fetch the evaluated object’s dependency graph, retrieves the coordinates of each vertex then computes the center of mass as the mean position among the set of vertices.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender mesh.

Returns

The coordinates of the center of mass of the mesh as a tuple(x, y, z).

Return type

tuple

goo.goo.get_contact_area()[source]

Calculate the contact ratio between cells in the scene.

This function computes the contact ratio between cell objects in the Blender scene. Loops over all cells. It considers the contact area between each pair of cells and calculates the ratio of the contact area to the total surface area of each cell.

Parameters

threshold (float) – The distance threshold to consider vertices in contact (default is 0.05).

Returns

A dictionary containing cell pairs as keys and their corresponding contact ratios and contact areas as values. The contact ratio represents the ratio of the contact area to the total surface area of each cell. The contact area represents the total area of contact between the cells.

Return type

dict, dict

goo.goo.get_division_angles(cell, alpha)[source]
goo.goo.get_forces_in_collection(obj)[source]

Get forces associated to the same cell.

This function retrieves force objects within the same collection as the provided Blender object that have a tag ‘object’ with the value ‘force’.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object whose collection is used for searching forces.

Returns

A list of objects within the same collection tagged as ‘force’.

Return type

list

goo.goo.get_forces_same_type(obj)[source]

Get cells of the same type.

This function retrieves forces of the same type as the provided Blender object, and looks across different collections. Checks the type custom properties of a Blender object, but outputs the associated force.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object representing a cell.

Returns

A list of force Blender object of the same type.

Return type

list

goo.goo.get_line_angles(cell, p1, p2)[source]

Calculate the angles between a line and the global axes.

This function calculates the angles between a line defined by two points (p1 and p2) and each of the global axes (x, y, z) of the given Blender cell.

Parameters

  • cell (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object representing the cell.

  • p1 (tuple) – The coordinates of the first point of the line.

  • p2 (tuple) – The coordinates of the second point of the line.

Returns

Angles between the line and each global axis in radians.

Return type

tuple

goo.goo.get_long_axis(obj)[source]

Calculates the long axis of a mesh.

This function calculates the first eigenvector of the vertices in the mesh, which corresponds to the long axis.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender mesh.

Returns

The coordinates of the long axis of the mesh as a tuple(x, y, z) which gives direction from the origin (0, 0, 0).

Return type

tuple

goo.goo.get_long_axis_global(obj)[source]

Calculates the long axis of a 3D object in global coordinates.

This function computes the long axis of a 3D object by determining the first eigenvector of its vertices’ positions in global coordinates.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender object for which to calculate the long axis.

Returns

A tuple representing the coordinates of the long axis in global space as (x, y, z), and the length of the long axis.

Return type

tuple

goo.goo.get_long_axis_np(obj)[source]

Calculates the long axis of a mesh.

This function calculates the first eigenvector of the vertices in the mesh, which corresponds to the long axis.

Parameters

obj (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The Blender mesh.

Returns

The coordinates of the long axis of the mesh as a tuple(x, y, z) which gives direction from the origin (0, 0, 0).

Return type

tuple

goo.goo.get_longaxis_angles(axis)[source]

Retrieves the 2 angles associated with the long axis of a cell.

Parameters

axis (tuple) – Coordinates of the long axis to the division plane as retrived by get_major_axis(obj).

Returns

  • phi (tuple) - Phi is the angle between the division axis and the z-axis in spherical coordinates.

  • theta (tuple) - Theta is the angle projected on the xy plane in cartesian 3D coordinates.

goo.goo.get_missing_adhesion_forces(obj1, obj2)[source]

Get adhesion forces missing between two objects.

This function identifies adhesion forces missing between two Blender objects. Adhesion forces are objects tagged with ‘object’ equal to ‘force’ and ‘motion’ equal to 0. It enforces daughter cells to inherit all adhesion forces from their cell type.

Parameters

  • obj1 (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The first Blender object.

  • obj2 (bpy.data.objects['name']) – The second Blender object.

Returns

A list of adhesion forces missing between the two objects.

Return type

list

class goo.goo.handler_class[source]

Bases: object

A class for creating different types of handlers that trigger actions on Goo cells when certain criteria are met.

The initialization function specifies available cell types and associated parameters like division rate, growth rate, and adhesion forces. It also initializes various data containers for simulation metrics.

adhesion_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for updating adhesion forces between cells.

This method updates the location and parameters of adhesion forces between cells. Adhesion forces are adapted to the size of the corresponding cells, and the force location is set to the center of mass of each associated cell.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

boundary_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for enforcing reflective boundaries on motion forces.

This method ensures that motion forces are constrained within the boundaries of a specified box or sphere. If a force location exceeds the box boundaries, it is reflected back into the box.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

contact_area_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]
data_export_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for exporting simulation data.

This method writes various simulation data to JSON files at the end of the simulation.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

division_handler_random(scene, despgraph)[source]
division_handler_volume(scene, despgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for cell division based on volume criteria.

This method is responsible for cell division based on volume criteria during the simulation. It loop over all cells, identifies candidate cells for division, selects the largest one, and then divides into two daughter cells.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • despgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

growth_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for cell growth based on mesh scaling.

This method calculates the volume and target volume of each cell, adjusts the shrink_min parameter of the Cloth modifier based on the deviation from the target volume, resulting in mesh scaling and mimicking cell growth.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

growth_pressure_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for cell growth based on cell’s pressure.

This method calculates the volume and target volume of each cell, adjusts the uniform pressure force based on the deviation from the target volume, and updates the pressure settings accordingly.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

launch_simulation(filepath, volume_scale=1, division_rate=50, start=1, end=250, motion_strength=-500, division_trigger='volume', adhesion=True, growth=False, division=False, data=False, motility=False, boundary=False)[source]

Launches the simulation with specified parameters.

This method initializes and launches the simulation based on the provided parameters. It sets up event handlers for various simulation aspects, including adhesion, data export, growth, division, motility, and boundary conditions.

Parameters

  • filepath (str) – The file path to save simulation data.

  • volume_scale (float) – Scaling factor for cell volumes.

  • division_rate (int) – The rate at which cells undergo division (in frames).

  • start (int) – The starting frame of the simulation.

  • end (int) – The ending frame of the simulation.

  • motion_strength (int) – Strength of motion applied to cells.

  • division_trigger (str) – The trigger for cell division (‘volume’ or ‘random’).

  • adhesion (bool) – Enable/disable adhesion in the simulation.

  • growth (bool) – Enable/disable cell growth in the simulation.

  • division (bool) – Enable/disable cell division in the simulation.

  • data (bool) – Enable/disable data export during the simulation.

  • motility (bool) – Enable/disable cell motility in the simulation.

  • boundary (bool) – Enable/disable boundary conditions in the simulation.

Returns

None

motion_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]
remeshing_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handlers responsible for remeshing cells at every time step.

It iterates over the cell objects in the scene, declares a remeshing modifier, and adjusts the mesh properties.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

stop_animation(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible to stop the simulation.

This method is called for each frame after the rendering is completed, and is executed only at the last time step. May be toggled to automatically quit Blender when the simulation is completed, which is needed when scanning parameter spaces.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

timing_elapsed_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Handler responsible for timing each frame during rendering.

This method is called for each frame after the rendering is completed. It is used to calculate the computational cost of each time step during rendering.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

timing_init_handler(scene, depsgraph)[source]

Initializes timing at the start of rendering.

This method is called when the rendering starts for Frame 1.

Parameters

  • scene – The Blender scene object.

  • depsgraph – The dependency graph object.

Returns

None

visualize_stretching(scene, depsgraph)[source]
goo.goo.make_cell(name, loc, type, radius=1, remeshing=True, scale=(1, 1, 1), stiffness=1, material=('bubble', 0.007, 0.021, 0.3), arcdiv=5, subdiv=3, mesh='icosphere')[source]

Creates a Blender cell object.

This function creates a new Blender cell object with various settings, such as mesh type, scale, material, and modifiers.

Parameters

  • name (str) – The name of the new cell object.

  • loc (tuple) – The location of the cell object.

  • type (str) – The type of the new cell object.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the cell object.

  • remeshing (bool) – Whether to apply remeshing modifiers.

  • scale (tuple) – The scale of the cell object.

  • stiffness (float) – The stiffness of the cloth modifier.

  • material (tuple) – The material properties for the cell.

  • arcdiv (int) – The arc divisions for the primitive_round_cube_add function.

  • subdiv (int) – The subdivision levels for the Subsurf modifier.

  • mesh (str) – The type of mesh to create (‘roundcube’ or ‘icosphere’).

Returns

None

goo.goo.make_collection(name, type)[source]

Create and link a new Blender collection to the scene.

This function creates a new collection with the given cell name and cell type, and links it to the current scene. Collections act as placeholder for cell types.

Parameters

  • name (str) – The name of the new collection.

  • type (str) – The type of the new collection.

Returns

The newly created collection.

Return type

bpy.types.Collection

goo.goo.make_force(force_name, cell_name, type, strength, falloff=0.5, motion=False, min_dist=0, max_dist=1.2)[source]

Creates a Blender force from a Goo Force object.

This function creates a Blender force object based on the provided parameters. It adds the force to the associated Blender collection and sets various force parameters such as strength, falloff, and motion.

Parameters

  • force_name (str) – The name of the force object.

  • cell_name (str) – The name of the associated cell object.

  • type (str) – The type of the cell.

  • strength (float) – The strength of the force.

  • falloff (float) – The falloff power of the force (default is 0.5).

  • motion (bool) – A flag indicating whether the force is a motion force (default is False).

  • min_dist (float) – The minimum distance for the force (default is 0).

  • max_dist (float) – The maximum distance for the force (default is 1.2).

Returns

The created Goo Force object.

Return type

Force

goo.goo.render(file_path, start, end)[source]

Renders a simulation to create a set of still images that can be made into a movie

Parameters

  • file_path (str) – The path of the folder used to store output images.

  • scene (bpy.context.scene) – The Blender current scene.

  • start (int) – The Blender starting frame.

  • end (int) – The Blender ending frame.

Returns

None

Forces a Blender cell object into a sphere shape.
